wCktWpTMeQVrkuin0u0c8A.text: Royal China's a good option for Chinese food if you're around Canary Wharf and don't feel like venturing out to Queensway for the really good stuff.  Good tofu dishes, including my all-time favorite, mapo tofu.

6RUk1oQ08dMYD-fhUpGZIw.text: Now I did a poor review of Waga's round here, this is totally the other end of the scale, absoloutely fantastic food. Every dish is worth a try. It is not the least expensive meal you'll ever eat but you really are paying for authentic quality. The cocktails are not a bad price though (£4.50) and if you want to go for broke the Sancerre is very nice (around 28 quid).The service is not exactly smiley - they do take themselves very seriously but it is one of the best chinese restaurants i have come accross in the capital. The portins are generous though, so be careful not to over order.I have only been at the weekend or the evening but I believe they do a lunch special which seems very good value, so if you work around here I can recommend stopping by for a bite. Also the view of the river is pretty special. Be a great place to take visiting parents.

h2t1X159SQT_QGA6eyqOiQ.text: This is a lovely waterside restaurant, decorated in black, royal blue and gold. I always come here as part of a large group for colleagues' birthday lunches. The staff are friendly and the service is super efficient, which is great when you only have an hour for a lunch break. The menu features safe stand bys like sweet and sour chicken but you have to sample the dim sum. It is superb. They also have a set menu for lunch which represents better value than the a la carte, although it's still pricey enough for it to be an ocassional treat rather than a regular Friday lunch-time outing. Booking is essential for lunches.

YyNjf-oOO11I6wwPZulPKw.text: Excellent top-class Chinese - not cheap but the food is worth the price. They do some excellent deep fried Noodles, which you can't get elsewhere, lots of authentic Chinese dishes on the menu. Dim Sum is not bad either. Good atmosphere inside - again very upmarket.

MVhM_gB3VqZwrWa26P5XFw.text: Royal China has very good dim sum and solid good cuisine every day.  When we lived in Canary Wharf, we ate there or had carry-out several times a week.  It was that good.  Big fan of their chicken with black bean sauce.  The location in Bayswater is good as well, but darker tunnel-like restaurant and is showing its age.

pWn7c2KOep6z2o2pe4btDw.text: One of my favorite places to get Dim sum. The food is fantastic for Dinner as well as Lunch. Staff are efficient, polite and very friendly. Interior is classy and authentic but the toilets are a little dark. This waterside restaurant has some great views especially around sunset. You may find the prices a little higher than the average Chinese restaurant but let me assure you it is well worth it. The Salt and pepper mixed seafood is a favorite of mine as well as the chicken and jelly fish dish both cooked to perfection. I would advise to book well in advance for both dinner and lunch.

SXjA-O__4LlCNbpx1YAnSQ.text: A very nice chinese restaurant located in a very nice place with a great view of the docklands! The food here is very nice and the prices are little exspensive than your usual chinese! The staff are very friendly and welcoming!

4Cv8F-Io9jOB1SsNJ5T53Q.text: great place liked it a lot will be going back

GvAaF7vT02tCUXTlNIrwcw.text: Top quality Chinese food any time of the day, but it's my favourite for dim sum. If you're going at the weekend be prepared for a long-ish wait but it's definitely worth it. An extensive menu, always prepared to an excellent standard, I keep coming back to Royal China again and again.

D64uISE_KYYCNkHGyKeT-Q.text: I've eaten dim sum all over the world and I swear this is the best I've ever tasted - better than Hong Kong! You have to queue for a table even if you arrive as they open on a Sunday but it's so worth the wait. Paper wrapped king prawns are phenomenal, great cheung fun - specials are always worth a try. And it's SO reasonable! Prices are fantastic. They're really family friendly too - both my children love eating there. It's amazing - try it.

COu2_ung5PJ0WcTLjpWgXg.text: Am truly surprised how others have rated this place so highly. Personally, I find the food to be totally unauthentic, with the menu hardly impressive either. The Dim Sum is sometimes served warm at best which is truly out of tradition and the speed at which food is served is horrendously slow. Just to add, the attitude of some of their waiters is poor - sometimes a little too cocky for their own good. Perhaps a decent view and benefits from being the closest Chinese restaurant from Canary Wharf, but I would say that is about it. For the price charged, there are better options in London.

1zRcz83fZ94IV14vbeIY9A.text: 'Alright' isn't what you'd expect from Royal China though. Their prices are higher than in Chinatown, but I couldn't see the difference. Dim sum is such a specialist area that a change of dim sum chef can affect the quality of food at a restaurant, and word spreads fast amongst the local Chinese community when this happens. I like the Canary Wharf location though, so I'm going to give Royal China one more try when it gets warmer, and have some dim sum by the Thames.

wKHHimthOZzJ5vZhf3Oq0w.text: This was a very nice Chinese restaurant experience for me, compared to the others I've had in the UK. The service was excellent, the food tasted great and the atmosphere was very comfortable... especially as I was enjoying the relaxing views of the Thames with my friends. Of course, it's not China, not Hong Kong, but what can you expect? Dim sum was good, if not the best I've had.

o2do-oUu9D6DT9x3eA_GSQ.text: Since I have never been to China, it was only when I went to the Royal China in Canary Wharf that I realized that all the chinese food I had eaten prior to this occasion was CRAP!In fact I don't know how the Royal China's food compare to the real chinese food in China; I know it's great food regardless. I know because of the richness of flavors, of tastes, the quality and quantity of ingredients, the freshness of products.Gold crispy fried chicken; or noodles with ginger; prawns or fish even the traditional sweet and sour (either pork or prawns) dish: everything has a richness of flavors that nowhere had I experienced before. Also the Sunday morning Dim Sum experience. Even the long wait on Sunday morning, when they operate a waiting list first to come - first to be served, didn't put me off.To the great foods add a good attentive and quick service, add the nice decor of the restaurant, the comfortable seating and the view of the river. Ideally one should arrive by boat, dock at the Canary Wharf docking station and just get to the chinese food feast!

8Pf1v4Za_0JsnrfRyd0G-w.text: Decent Chinese food but a bit expensive for what you get. I didn't like the twice-cooked pork and for some strange reason they chopped off the ends of the bok choy, which was otherwise good. The mabo tofu was the best of what we ordered. It might be worth going back to sample some other dishes but I'm going to try my luck elsewhere first. I think London can do better than a 3 star Chinese joint.

xRzGY3AFGP-DeZRVWtNvnw.text: Got takeaway here for dinner while traveling and couldn't have been happier.  The food was delicious, and the staff was very kind and helpful.  Of course, it is quite expensive, but everything in this neighborhood is, unfortunately.

fGwh2nJVYVjYjHX47BL-5w.text: This has the same name as the one in Bayswater and they look related to me...I've been lucky enough to have both eaten here and had take out for a late night at work.Both times have been very good. I had the pleasure of taking some colleagues to dine in - some of which had never had dim sum before?! I know right?!Suffice to say, they enjoyed it a lot, bar the cost which is to be expected in this area.As for take out - they delivered on time and correctly. The food was also still hot which is a must for delivered food, especially Asian.

oy9CK-KMNUBhyiqdRYfsjA.text: There aren't many places to go to around the Canary Wharf area if you are looking for Chinese food. Royal China is the most prominent one that is located at Westferry Circus. I came here for dinner a while ago before they had a refurbishment. Pan fried stuffed eggplant with minced shrimp in black bean sauce £9.8Eggplant cooked until it was soft and soaking in the black bean sauce. This had a slight spicy kick to it. Mixed seafood stir fried with fresh milk £14.80When I saw this on the menu, I Just HAD to order it. I mean stir fried fresh milk? The dish came out in a blanket of fluffy snow interspersed with seafood. The texture was like the filling in egg tarts with hints of sweet coconut if I'm not mistaken. I really enjoyed this.Squid with garlic and chilli £11.50This was unmemorable. Overall dinner was satisfying though the prices here are a little more on the £££ side. On another occasion, I came back during the May long weekend for some dim sum with friends. Usually this wouldn't be my first pick but they were having a promotion for the month of May with 25% off. With a large table, we got down to ordering and they have some new items introduced into the menu. Where do I begin? Having had dim sum here in the past, I always thought it was respectable if not ever a tad expensive for the quality.Let's start with the newcomers. Underwhelmingly disappointing. The fish dumplings were over steamed and dry. The taro cake was slices of taro that were pressed together but doesn't gel as it should like a turnip cake and lacked any taste. The green tea sponge cake? There are no words. Back to the regulars, the quality and standard were inconsistent with some being good and others disappointing. Compared to my previous visits, there is a distinct drop in quality.  We finished the dim sum with dessert with one of the party ordering the sago cream with yam and the rest had the sweet dumplings. Desserts itself took over half an hour to arrive and having made these sweet dumplings before, it doesn't take half an hour. When it arrived, I was so disappointed that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. The dumpling had a crackling texture instead of being chewy and QQ; the soup did not even have any hint of ginger! Having spent that long waiting for our dessert, it was another 20 minutes for our bill to arrive. With a young child in tow, you bet the little boy was pretty restless by this stage. We finally went to the counter to pay our bill and to our surprise, there was no discount. We queried with the lady who served us and the answer we got was the bill is generated via a machine that is maintained by head office and it seems that head office had excluded the discount from the machine and sales today. Lady, how difficult is it to whip out a calculator and manually write or deduct the discount if your machine is malfunctioning?I don't know about you but when I am greeted by this discount advert sign when walking through canary wharf after the dim sum with no discount, bad service and disappointing food, something is seriously wrong and disappointing here. Misleading advertising is what I will begin with.

FWOXe679NlxMUyus4wcVsw.text: Rather decent Cantonese grub for Canary Wharf, comparable with what one would find in high-brow establishments in Hong Kong, in my opinion.  I had expected to pay over five pounds an order of dim sum, turns out they hover between three to four.  Doors open at 1130 on Saturdays but be warned that tables fill up quickly.  Outdoor seating is not recommended on exceptionally windy days, unless you enjoy drinking tea with fresh tree leaves in it.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

KwwZJGx5bzSrJoZf-ti7KQ.text: This is a high-end dim sum (yum char) restaurant in Canary Wharf and the food is the best that I have had in a dim sum restaurant in London so far.  It all seems freshly cooked to me and I enjoyed every dish.  Often, the dumplings are what lets a restaurant down, but they were great here.The service was also above average and I would happily come back here with a bigger group of friends.(Also, I would echo the comment of some of the other reviewers - the location of this restaurant is incorrect on the googlemaps extract.)

Wlc1KrlLS9R_sYI8I_cKoA.text: My dimsum experiences are varied. Yuautcha is at the very top end of the scale (still the best I've ever had in my life, and indeed one of the best meals), Ping Pong is at the bottom. I hate Ping Pong. In the middle? Nothing. Except my cooking from scratch because I happen to live over the road from a Chinese supermarket. Royal China is placed somewhere happily in the middle. Sunday lunch meant that the restaurant (apparently newly refurbished) was full of Chinese families all tucking in to little parcels and lots of noodles. As with most dimsummeries, it's very child-friendly and there's prams and high chairs all over the shop (in an accommodating way, not in a yummy mummy kind of way). But Sunday lunch meant a 20 minute wait. And it was totally worth it. There was three of us, which for the most part meant ordering was successful. No one dish stood out, they were all really very good. Scallop dumplings probably my favourite. Specials aren't much pricier than the usual dishes (and actually, I didn't think they were any better or most interesting). Tea is cheap, staff are friendly. We could have happily ordered more than our three dishes each (actually, we did happily order more) so 12 dishes, plus tea came to a healthy £50 in total. I'm impressed. I'm now on the hunt for ALLTHEDIMDUMINLONDON, but I imagine if I'm on this side of the river (and I frequently am), Royal China will get many visits from me. 50% of which will be hungover on a Sunday afternoon.

Sdu3BrtQ0SoQG_3u2cF_kQ.text: My husband and I love frequenting Royal China for special occasions. I love the location as it sits alongside the Thames River. You can take a stroll along the river walk before or after your meal. The restaurant itself has great quality food. I also appreciate how it has a vegetarian tasting menu which I have thoroughly enjoyed. They also have a well priced drink menu. I like the interior decorations and the food is very flavorsome and authentic. My only complaint is that the service is very slow and they always seem to be running around in a hurry. However- I enjoy the food every time we go and love the location! Definitely great for vegetarians.

tW9b40G0esUsE2q-nSJHtQ.text: Wow.Had an awful experience with them just now. Wanting to order some take away from them I called up and checked they do it - nice woman says yes - they only do delivery on weekdays though.No problems, we think.We work through their website which is half chinese so quite promising in terms of food quality and authentic charm. All the prices are on it even if it still has a page inviting people to their Christmas dinner.My colleague calls back to place the order, about 17 quid for me and 35 quid for him. At the end my colleague asks how much it will be and the telephone man wanders off to get a calculator and then comes back saying it's £106. Gob-smacked we laugh a bit and say, "No, really - how much?".Then he just won't back down. First he says that they are already cooking the first order - which is a bit of blackmail we didn't really need - but that's ok. We know it's just a simple mistake somewhere and then soon we can be enjoying wonderful chinese food.My colleague is trying to find out if the guy has taken down something wrong since the price seems to have doubled so he goes through the items and prices and they're all about right (the rice was 20p more expensive - it doesn't matter when we're talking about a surcharge of £50). So are the quantities. However the guy on the phone keeps on repeating that it's £106 and that my colleague had better pay this.Then he starts shouting.So my colleague hangs up. Then his mobile goes - yes - they called him back to shout at him some more so my colleague says, "I don't want to talk to you just now".After a few minutes of fuming, then he calmly calls up the restaurant again and speaking to the woman who answers the phone he says he had just put in an order and wants to talk to the manager to explain what just happened.Nope - she starts shouting down the phone that he'd better pay for his food and that we owe them £106. Shouting over my colleagues attempts to explain that we didn't order that much and that we'd got them to repeat the prices and quantities.All I can say is to avoid these stupid bullies. No matter what has happened (and we definitely were right as we confirmed with the first guy) there is no excuse for people shouting down the phone.

uEuZK6fIaCjfg_fIAsZ1SA.text: This is an upscale Chinese restaurant with the atmosphere and décor to match... black lacquered accents and linen tablecloths - the ambiance is very nice.  The location is especially great since you're overlooking the water... charming views of Canary Wharf and the city... I was on a date and found this be a fabulous date-like setting.Service is very attentive and patient - they were happy to answer all of our questions and they gave us a great wine recommendation. Even though it was super-busy the food came out quite fast.I had a kung pao broccoli dish, which was sufficiently spicy - exactly what you'd want it to be.  My date had a pork and cashew dish, which he said was also flavourful.  Neither one was a let-down. They seem to have a lot of regular customers here, or else there're a few recommended dishes that we didn't know about, since most of the people seemed to be ordering the same thing.  There was an especially interesting sculptural bird-looking thing that kept coming out on plates.  We didn't ask what it was... but I'll definitely inquire about it the next time I go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. bird thing - what is it?
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

nxLZWcD6srMeDXyN9pEGRA.text: The best-positioned of the Royal China chain, beside the Thames at Canary Wharf and with a stunning view of the City three miles upstream. Go early at weekends as there is no booking at lunchtime; instead soak up the sun afterwards with a stroll by the river. But you don't go for the view but for the superb fresh food, and particularly excellent dim sum. But don't forget to have the the chicken's feet in black bean sauce; you won't be disappointed, even if your non-Chinese friends back away. Interestingly, the waiters here speak Mandarin, while in most of the other Royal China group, they speak Cantonese (ie they are from Hong Kong).

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Royal China Canary Wharf at lunchtime
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Royal China. Next door is a Gaucho

9iqI2tx_a6nvxNo0ix2ihA.text: I recently brought some colleagues to Royal China for a meal and I think it was enjoyed by all.  I love Royal China and have been coming with my family since I was a little girl, both for dim sum and evening meals.  I don't think I've ever had a bad meal here. On this occasion, we had various starters, including salt and chili squid (personal favourite), sesame prawn toast and chicken satay.  The squid didn't disappoint.  For mains we had deep fried chicken, prawn cakes and Chinese broccoli, Cantonese beef and topped off with Portuguese seafood rice, which is by far the star dish at Royal China.  I have had this at other restaurants around London, and it is always best here - the seafood tastes fresh and the sauce has the right level of coconut and sweetness - it's well worth trying (although you probably won't see it on the menu...).  I can't fault the service, the food or the location of this Royal China, since it is right by the river which allows you to have an alfresco meal, if you choose to.

_7co1z8hafJP9k0gM-wpzA.text: Delightful and quite authentic. Actually feels like China in the dining room. Dim Sum is excellent. Main dishes are well prepared and are served in reasonable portions. Only drawback are the prices. You pay for the quality. Is it worth it? For me, yes. But, occasionally.

wAkLtdDqh2Q8FIYfSKRiCQ.text: Busy, busy especially on weekends. Agree that it fills a hole in the yum cha market around Docklands/Canary Wharf and I like that it is there when I feel like some traditional Chinese dim sum. Not the best in the world, but I have always found good yum cha harder to come by in London. Still, a nice yum cha offering and a great place for leisure or business, in my opinion. Prices are a little higher.

sib3CzKwMgA4YUqS58_wBg.text: I've eaten at Royal China twice now and haven't the faintest idea why everyone sings its praises so highly. Don't get me wrong, it's good at what it does, but after all the hype (I'd been told that this restaurant's the only one that comes close to doing dim sum Hong Kong style), the food was a bit of a disappointment. I'm not a dim sum aficionado, I'll admit, but I think I've eaten enough of it in Singapore and Hong Kong to tell what's good and what's not, and, as I said, Royal China serves good food, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. What I would definitely recommend is the crispy noodles which were delicious, as well as the spinach in oyster sauce, which was a little on the salty side, but came nicely presented. Admittedly, it as pricey at £9.60 given it was just, well, spinach! The turnip cake was really nice as well. I expected a little better for the baked pork chop with chilli sand salt. Not enough chilli and too much salt, I say. The char siew (roasted pork) - my must-have in any dim sum restaurant - was okay, not the best I've had in London. Service was friendly; they certainly didn't have any issues with my ordering in a combination of Mandarin, Cantonese and English, unlike some of the restaurants in Chinatown. The view from this restaurant is great. It's located right by the river and just incredibly relaxing.

kAS7ncw6skHo8P99iDQeqQ.text: Royal China offers authentic Chinese food in Canary Wharf  something the Wharf is somewhat lacking. The dim sum is delicious, and the main meat dishes aren't bad either. It can be difficult to get a table at the weekend, especially on a Sunday, despite the size of the place, so don't be surprised if you need to wait an hour or more. Booking is definitely a good idea.The prices are a little high, but you certainly get what you pay for, and it's definitely more of a treat place than a regular indulgence.

vEzISg_XE9HkKswvVkvIFw.text: Our favourite Chinese restaurant in London. I love the location- right on the river.

0UEPDz9egG6KqSs_1DFlWw.text: For photos, please go to chopstix2steaknives.blog… There aren't many places to go to around the Canary Wharf area if you are looking for Chinese food. Royal China is the most prominent one that is located at Westferry Circus.I came here for dinner a while ago before they had a refurbishment.Pan fried stuffed eggplant with minced shrimp in black bean sauce £9.8Eggplant cooked until it was soft and soaking in the black bean sauce. This had a slight spicy kick to it.Mixed seafood stir fried with fresh milk £14.80When I saw this on the menu, I Just HAD to order it. I mean stir fried fresh milk? The dish came out in a blanket of fluffy snow interspersed with seafood. The texture was like the filling in egg tarts with hints of sweet coconut if I'm not mistaken. I really enjoyed this.Squid with garlic and chilli £11.50This was unmemorable. Overall dinner was satisfying though the prices here are a little more on the £££ side.On another occasion, I came back during the May long weekend for some dim sum with friends. Usually this wouldn't be my first pick but they were having a promotion for the month of May with 25% off.With a large table, we got down to ordering and they have some new items introduced into the menu. Where do I begin? Having had dim sum here in the past, I always thought it was respectable if not ever a tad expensive for the quality.Let's start with the newcomers.Underwhelmingly disappointing. The fish dumplings were over steamed and dry. The taro cake was slices of taro that were pressed together but doesn't gel as it should like a turnip cake and lacked any taste. The green tea sponge cake? There are no words.Back to the regulars, the quality and standard were inconsistent with some being good and others disappointing. Compared to my previous visits, there is a distinct drop in quality.We finished the dim sum with dessert with one of the party ordering the sago cream with yam and the rest had the sweet dumplings.Desserts itself took over half an hour to arrive and having made these sweet dumplings before, it doesn't take half an hour. When it arrived, I was so disappointed that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. The dumpling had a crackling texture instead of being chewy and QQ; the soup did not even have any hint of ginger!Having spent that long waiting for our dessert, it was another 20 minutes for our bill to arrive. With a young child in tow, you bet the little boy was pretty restless by this stage. We finally went to the counter to pay our bill and to our surprise, there was no discount. We queried with the lady who served us and the answer we got was the bill is generated via a machine that is maintained by head office and it seems that head office had excluded the discount from the machine and sales today. Lady, how difficult is it to whip out a calculator and manually write or deduct the discount if your machine is malfunctioning?I don't know about you but when I am greeted by this discount advert sign when walking through canary wharf after the dim sum with no discount, bad service and disappointing food, something is seriously wrong and disappointing here. Misleading advertising is what I will begin with.

SKQHOKcqzQgaH-5iT_6waA.text: Came here for dim-sun. Not the best, but not the worse, and it's in a good location for a walk towards to old pubs in old Limehouse or to Canary WharfFilled a hole anyways

BxNz3wVr-cKMj0YJmWPVIw.text: Good food but very very overpriced. Not worth the cost. These are Soho prices and the staff and service are a bit odd and uncaring. There is another amazing Chinese Restaurant very nearby called the China Palace. It's in front of the Excel Centre. The food is easily as good as here, if not better, and the price is a fraction of the Royal China's.

1f3oTaAEUHTaDCr8ebNzjQ.text: Royal China is one of the upmarket Chinese places outside of China-Town. Located in Canary Wharf if has prices to match but the decor and food are very good. In short: There is often a wait for a table so it's good to arrive at a time other people might not. The food is also slightly higher priced that you might expect and if you add drinks it's going to be a big bill (evening menu). For Dim-Sum it's very high quality with only a small selection of generic dishes. I enjoyed this Restaurant a lot, but they need a few more floor staff for the busier periods. In addition there doesn't appear to be free parking unlike other Chinese restaurants nearby. I really liked their Tofu and Aubergine dishes, very good. Great place to take a date :) They could improve the seating layout a bit and the number of staff, but overall it's a great place.

NFYemLKpVXnzn_P_0gWMcA.text: I hate leaving a one star review, but Royal China dearly deserved it.I wanted to try something in Canary Wharf which wasn't a national restaurant chain, so we settled on Royal China.Right from the off, I could tell something was dubious about this place. It had the pretence of a traditional Chinese restaurant, with none of the charming decor. It all felt off-colour, inside, as though they'd tried to modernise the interior but it just ended up looking a bit dated.Royal China's biggest downfall however, is their service. We hadn't reserved, so were duly told we had to be out within 80 minutes. Not a big deal, sure, but the restaurant was largely empty and we were only a table of two. As it happens, the restaurant did get busier, but there were still plenty of free tables as we left.I'm pretty certain our waitress absolutely hated us. She didn't welcome us, was very abrupt, barely gave us time to look at the menu and didn't crack a single smile all night. And then I noticed all the staff were exactly the same.I decided to try something new, and settled on Eel. My partner decided to go for a chicken noodle dish. Reading the menu, it listed one of the ingredients in my dish as containing MSG, and I politely requested to have my food without it.The waitress honked "HUH?" at me twice before swiftly turning away, returning to write something in Mandarin on the table and walking off again. Wow.The food came out after a short wait, and neither dish was particularly appetising. The noodles in the chicken dish were overly greasy and a mixture of crunchy and soggy. The Eel dish left me feeling rather ill afterwards.Bad food, horrific service and an awkward atmosphere.Hilarously, they included their service charge in the bill. Whilst this is standard practice across London's dining establishments, such places also offer.. y'know.. service. On our way out, the staff didn't bother saying bye or wishing us a good evening. I can't recommend you avoid this restaurant enough. Worst restaurant I've ever been to.

fVGkL_iEDrMTrJjp78is4Q.text: We stopped at the Royal China Canary Wharf prior to popping over to a movie at West India Quay. Right on the water and a short walk from the DLR Westferry stop, it is a nice walk and view if you have some time to spare.The food and ambiance is the same quality as the Bayswater location and was quite busy on a Saturday around almost 2pm. Our order was taken quickly and came out piping out. The egg tarts here are probably one the best dim sum items they have. Flaky pastry and light creamy custard!

T9gg642xWDJt-I2W9Glo3Q.text: Best Chinese restaurant around canary wharf area.Good dim sum and Cantonese food. By the river near the dock. Service is alright but compare to other Chinese restaurant you can hardly ask for more.

GfNzHXHCyAu5Jp5rnhxzSA.text: Service was excellent this time! Service has improved tremendously since the last two times we had been to this restaurant the food remains excellent great view nice atmosphere.

_kvHCftnqVJ4kdGoy5aZmQ.text: I like Royal China, as they do consistently good dim sum...although a pricey one. What I particularly like about this location is...the location. Right by the Westferry Terminal in Canary Wharf, I heartily recommend to take the ferry from Embankment or Tower Bridge all the way over here...that way you combine a little sightseeing tour with some really good food.Afterwards, and please refer to the other reviews on what to order etc., I recommend you walk back along the Thames. There are some truly wonderful views to be admired and some lovely pubs along the way - my favorite being The Grapes. As for the dim sum, be prepared to wait and be prepared to receive mediocre service...

LWpOgAiPgPZDlR7a7L7YFQ.text: The main reason why I'd visit this place again is the fact that in summer you can eat al fresco with a beautiful view of the Thames and the close proximity to Canary Wharf. You can certainly expect the meal to be served in proper Chinese style with all parts of the course being presented on the table separately.Although the food is well prepared the price is disproportionally high in comparison to the amounts served.It is however one of the restaurants I would think of when planning to eat in fresh open air.

pOguWzDkmSSZP1IX_SAuaw.text: Quick review:+ ok food- very pricey- small portion- service could be betterFull review:I came here for dinner on a Saturday night and was encouraged by the venue packed with Chinese diners, but somehow it didn't live up to my expectation. The prices are very dear for Chinese food, but perhaps not for the location. Still, £20 for a plate of fish in cream corn sauce was enough to put me off, as lovely as the picture menu makes out the food to be. Some of the staff extended warm service, particularly those who greeted and welcomed diners at the door. But once seated, the waitress seemed more impatient. For example, when taking our drinks order, we asked which wine we should try, and the waitress bluntly said she didn't know anything about wine. And as we examined the drinks menu, she took off without a word, instead of uttering something nice like "I'll give you a few minutes," as one could expect from a "posh" restaurant (come on, £20 for a main dish, that's posh, right?). The food itself tasted good, but portion size is very small and given the price, it's not great value.

H2UJt5tHAC39vMRiEafEZw.text: All is good food service and surroundings but 3£ for rice per is an insult and a rip off

hM2keE0qZFycNrhZnUvoMA.text: I've often walked passed Royal China but never ventured in until a friend from the U.S. came to visit.  It was mid-July and the height of our heat wave.  We were looking for somewhere for lunch on that Sunday afternoon and the tables shaded under the trees looked inviting so we went in.  We got a table under the trees with a view out over the river, cool and relaxing.We were waiting to get menus and a while again to get drinks and that's how the service continued throughout the meal.  But the wait was worth it.  We had the most delicious dim-sum and the best pancake rolls I've ever had.We enjoyed the meal so much we returned for dinner a few days later.  We were disappointed to see the extensive dim-sum offered at lunch was not available, but the odd one or two can be found in the evening menu, although they're not quite as appetizing as the dim-sum available at lunch.  We had pancake rolls again but they weren''t prepared in the same way as at lunch and not as good - we were disappointed.  We did have, however, the most exquisite soft-shell crab - yum, yum, yum, yum, yum!Great food, not so great service.

e0xx3RCt9DiqD3htrwR8dw.text: Please note: this reivew is for dinner only.  After a lovely couple of cocktails at Camino, hubby and I ventured over to get a bite at Royal China.  The servers were busy but really seemed too rushed to get our orders. Minis one point right there!  Every time I tried to get my waitresses' attention, she barely looked at me! We ordered a glass of sauv blanc and rose sparking wine, both light and delicious. I had the hot and sour soup, vegetarian.  This was NOT recommended. had no flavor--had to douse it in soy sauce and vinegar to get it to an eatable state When I mentioned that it wasnt good, I got a nasty look.  OK sorrrrry, then please dont ask! As a starter we also ordered the pork dumplings, and they were awesome. I would come back just for those. hubby ordered a spicy chicken dish that was really not spicy but tasted good,All in all, I might go for the dumplings and try the dim sum but dinner? not so much.

WuE6NRBM-f6GnvZFaQfegQ.text: I stopped in here after spotting it on a nice walk along Canary Warf. The restaurant was fairly packed, which is always a good sign. I must say, the food was fantastic. I had the crispy beef and it was very tasty. The atmosphere was lovely too. The service wasn't great, the waitress who took our order was very abrupt, with little patience. Mind you, the other staff who served us were very friendly so maybe she was just having a bad day. What i didn't particularly like was the recommended service charge of 13% which was automatically added to the bill. When I tip, I like to feel I have the choice and that it is based on service, rather than it being assumed that they will receive the tipOverall, it was a great meal!

yqSeczPM26t7YJjSk4JaYA.text: Favourite place in London to go for dim sum. I've been coming here since I was a child. It's so serene by the waterside, the dim sum is always delicious and fresh! They have a specials card if you're feeling adventurous, but still an excellent place for dim sum purists. Service is always friendly and courteous. If you go on a nice day, you can get on the Thames clipper which stops directly outside for a short cruise down the river straight into the centre of town! It's always thronging with people on the weekend, so be prepared to take a ticket and wait! Wait is well worth it though!

QLtaPRRk3mqt7EyHUBiyyA.text: This is restaurant serves up your typical dim sum. All the stuff they offer is well made.  But they lack other things like tripe.  I like tripe.  It is a bit more pricey than other places for dim sum.  Kinda upscale like other reviewers mentioned.  If you go around noon (when it opens on the weekend) then you should be able to get a seat.  The reason I'm giving it 4 stars instead of just 3 is due to the fact that it has an outdoor seating area along the Thames.  Eating good dim sum on a sunny day along the river? BlissfulThe map location given by google maps is not correct.  It is closer to the  river.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Outdoor seating
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

EeBJ0922MITLTtVOoK4_EQ.text: Everything is so tasty here especially dim sum. Staffs could be more polite and courteous. Most of them running around the tables like speedy Gonzales.  That's the only tip the restaurant can review and improve over time.  Order anything, they are all super delicious.

QEmKHucqI47XXE_cl_RjWw.text: Good location by the River and especially in the summer. There was a time when Royal China was the go to place for higher end Chinese food in London, however  times have changed with a host of other new and fancy restaurant choices available. Royal China is being left behind. The décor is now starting to show its age, and when combined with the fairly standard Cantonese menu and service, it no longer justifies the trek out to Canary Wharf. This was demonstrated by the fact that the place wasn't packed on Chinese New Year!

cIzEf828VOQZ2CPO-WWxgA.text: Last day of full day in London, lunch on 3.14.10. Dim sum = limited selection, and you have to order it, no carts!  Food was average, unsurprisingly. And this place also seems tourist-y...as evidenced by the drunk couple in the booth next to us, nursing glasses of white wine.........Freakin long wait in queues.  Prices = expensive!Decor =simple, appears roomy with lots of glass.Views= spectacularSave your quid and go elsewhere, plenty of great places in London for Chinese food, especially dim sum!

4GyQrBxI5xD9zW_WkEvp2g.text: Went here last weekend while I was in London and really enjoyed the food. I had never been before so the other people who had been there before ordered.The chicken dish was particular tasty. Mmmmmm!! Other dishes was sea bass which was a particular large one and very nice. As well as a veg dish we also had a beef dish. Not sure what its called but it was beef in a very hot sandpot which kept the food hot all the way through meal. With the beef were Japanese mushrooms (Enokitake). The beef does was also DELICIOUS!!I have rated this 5/5. If honest its not 5/5 as its not "perfect". Nothing is perfect!! The veg dish was very nice but not "spectacular" and it was more expensive than a normal Chinese restaurant in somewhere like Chinatown. (Well Chinatown in Manchester anyway!!)The restaurant was by the Thames so sure the view was good but it was too dark to see anything when we went.(Just realised there are 2 instances of this Royal China restaurant. This instance already had 6 reviews so I have added mine here. I have notified Yelp about the other one which only had my review).(Sorry if this has caused any problems!!)

As2IOiF4qb1u0maDopi0MQ.text: Love the setting opposite the water in Canary wharf and easy walking distance.Always busy when I have been so good sign of a well regarded restaurant. Quality Chinese food and the Dim Sum and seafood are excellent  very fresh!Price is not bad but feel slightly higher than should be and that is why not awarding 5* but without doubt my favourite Asian restaurant in Canary Wharf where I am sure if you take friends they will be impressed.

kY_rYsD7YOqBLhSEvLb9Sw.text: Did you know that the most expensive food ever was an Italian truffle, sold at over $200,000?This restaurant probably puts Italian truffle powder in their food, that's the only explanation for the price.Anyway, we had some trouble finding this place. For some reason Google Maps gave us the wrong directions. For those that need help finding this place, go to the roundabout a Westferry Circus. Then, go towards the river and walk down the stairs. Royal China is next to the outdoor elevator.Service is average. The staff weren't particularly nice, but they weren't mean either. Although, for something this fancy, I'd expect better. Also, while all the waiters and hosts speak Mandarin, the menus have Chinese, and the dishes are authentically Asian, this restaurant felt like a Western establishment. The table set-up and aesthetics are Western-style, and dishes are ordered per person, rather than shared for the group.The food was fairly average. It's decent, but not extra good or special, when compared to a restaurant that costs two times less.For two people, we ordered 2 bowls of seafood soup, 2 bowls of white rice, and split 1 beef dish. That came out to be £27.57. That's 0.014% of the world's most expensive food. Estimating our dinner to be "worth" about half the price, I can only imagine that the other £15 in cost came from the 0.1035 grams of Italian truffle they added to our meal.

3EqUn7zsekUkqOUKBSF6GA.text: it's an ok cantonese style restaurant for dianxin, visited many times nothing special just had decent meals there, good environment due to the price.

AVGm0Bdja6yRoI3u216tpQ.text: Very good, high quality Chinese cuisine with a great location right by the Thames.  There's plenty of outdoor seating to take advantage of the water views, too.   Service is polite and timely, though can be a little on the brisk side.  However, the quality and flavor of the food more than makes up for it.  On our first visit, we had salt & pepper squid (simply delicious, with really nice hot peppers); spicy pork chili steamed dumplings (very good); really tiny baby bok choi in delicate garlic sauce; Chinese broccoli; and steamed scallops in black bean sauce (a nice combination of the subtle fresh scallop flavor and the funky fermented black beans - though not overpowering at all); and an excellent Peking duck.  We liked the food so much we came back a second time and tried their steamed sea bass in ginger and scallion which was also excellent, spanking fresh, and I liked the exquisite way in which they deboned (not filleted!) the fish so that there no bones to deal with yet maintaining the presentation of the whole fish.  Well done!Unfortunately, we didn't get to try their dim sum as it was only available during lunch hours but if we ever get back there, we'll make time for it as they looked mouth-wateringly good.  The place fills up fast - and much of the clientele is Asian (which is a good sign for its quality) - so I do recommend reservations.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Peking duck (top); salt&pepper squid (left); baby bok choi (right)
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

MU_JXFBB2qg4P4FjShow3w.text: Overpriced dim sum as bill came in at more than £20 per person for a dim sum meal. The quality is similar to Chinatown or nearby china boat restaurant (near south Quay Station). I can recommend the glazed pork buns as they seemed to be more fresh and genuinely worth its value. Another thing I don't like is that they don't have a check box style menu ordering AND they had 3 different menu cards. Very confusing. Drop the price, increase the quantity or quality. Very bad price / quality combo.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Standard dim sum - do note that the chilli sauce is quite thin
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Green egg yolk buns - - they are okay but not fantastic. Your average bakery does a better job
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Honey glazed pork buns (only recommended dish for its price point)

mRB07cti4kIkEZcZGkxMxQ.text: We came here for lunch and the restaurant was busy and crowded.  A very popular spot!  The dim sum was good but everything was just slightly off.Har gow was filled with big chunks of shrimp but the wrapper was too thin and broke easily.  Siu mai looked great but weren't as tasty as I was hoping.  Beef cheung fun needed more seasoning and the soy sauce dressing could have been sweeter.  Glutinous rice wrapped lotus leaf seemed to have the wrong kind of rice - too long, not sweet enough.Everything we ordered was missing just a little something.  Nothing was awful but nothing stood out either.  I was hoping for better quality dim sum given the higher end nature of Royal China.

EIId3Z96MuHm3PsL8BZJLQ.text: I've been putting off writing a review but I'm finally getting down to it fresh off the back of a weekend dinner with a party of 7.I booked the table just 4 hours earlier (because I'm not a square...) and there was no problem at all. We were able to be seated immediately after our arrival during peak weekend dinner rush.On my previous visits I'd only dined at lunch and ordered from the dim sum menu. I encourage everyone to come and try it. It's a great experience and much better than the vast majority of places in Central. There will be a line though... so arrive early or arrive late.This time because it was evening and we had so many people I was really able to go crazy with the menu. We ordered Peking duck, soup, so many different types of dishes and even dessert. So here's the skinny:This place gets busy... although booking isn't essential especially on week days, it's a good idea to call ahead even by an hour or two and make a booking anyway. You'll be really glad you did once you see the line going out of the door during meal rush because if there's one thing everyone can agree on about us Chinese folk... it's that we LOVE to eat and will queue for a ridiculous amount of time for a good meal.Although I rate this restaurant highly, I will say that you should steer away from Northern Chinese or Sichuanese dishes here since this restaurant (and its associated restaurants around London) specialises in Canton cuisine. This means yes on dim sums, soups, stir fried greens, seafood and anything that's not spicey but no on anything that resembles Sichuanese cuisine or spicy 'fragrant' dishes (mapo tofu is a good example.) This is not a criticism of the restaurant but rather a reflection of the fact that China is a LARGE country and the food varies vastly between each region so it's unreasonable to expect a Canton restaurant to make really good Sichuanese or Northern style food.Instead, order all the dim sum you can eat because it's excellent here. Cantonese roast duck is a delight. Scallops, steamed fish, soups and stir fried greens (my favourite is gai lan, a kale like vegetable). If you're longing for a taste of Beijing, I'd avoid the Beijing duck here. Although is it passable I would only call it 'Beijing' duck when feeling generous. It is more like a Cantonese roast duck served up 'Beijing' style and at around £50 it's an expensive mistake to make if you are not prepared. Service at Royal China is top notch. I always seem to catch May when she's working and she's always been so kind and attentive. It really makes the experience worthwhile since finding a Chinese/Cantonese restaurant with good food AND good service is almost impossible.An added bonus is that you can hop on the River Bus at Westferry right on their doorstep to Westminster Pier! This goes the other way too of course. :P

Y80T-0qQH9U0AB9Tk2uISg.text: Good Dim sum is about impossible to find in Europe. Royal China is expensive and the menu is narrow but what they do have is well executed. Steamed dumplings are cooked properly. Not to sticky. The flavours are bright and fresh.

Cy5hPLhOlnZEyN48mYubPw.text: The food was filling and delicious, but the dessert was frozen. The staff wouldn't let us sit outside... They said it was too windy.

MMoYCSxXv1Z3YTDvGmXXMg.text: There's some very fine dim sum here. The prawn dumplings and Shanghai soup dumplings were particularly good. Squid cakes not so good. It's quite expensive for dim sum, but it's in canary wharf overlooking the river, whaddya expect?! Another couple who came after into a largely empty restaurant (at 3pm) asked not to sit between the few busy tables and asked to sit a couple of tables away, but the waiter said rest of the restaurant is closed and insisted they sit between two other tables. That seemed mean.However they treated us well throughout. And they were cool about us sitting chatting for over an hour after we'd finished eating (it was raining very hard outside).

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Fukien rice
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

AkBYyACidsrrkwWmwdtj9Q.text: meh.. Being a Taiwanese and had Chinese food throughout my life, this place is pretty dreadful. The rice was flat and mushy like baby food. The dumpling wrapper was so thick and so much dough that I felt like I was eating fried bread rolls. The service was abysmal. We ordered Prawn & Pork Wonton Soup, mixed vegetables noodles, Dumplings, and "Shaolin Monks" Vegetables served in Clay Pot. The wonton soup and clay plot were actually not too bad (hence the two stars). The dinner came with complimentary small sides: fried peanuts and cucumbers. The cucumbers had been submerged in the water/seasoning for too long though so they were sour (not from vinegar) and soggy, not crunchy or fresh. The restaurant is located at a prime location right next to the water. The view is amazing. The food is meh..

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

Ve0PP3qhgT4ZInCQ4cU-lw.text: We went with a big group for dim sum on a Sunday, and grabbed a table just before 12. They were full by 12:15, and there was a pretty long queue after that, so worth arriving early or late on Sundays if possible!We shared a number of options, and service was professional and quick although brusque as at other locations. As a vegetarian, I was pleased that there are more veggie options than at some places, particularly as they offer both their full menu as well as a dim sum menu (which only has a couple vegetarian options, really). Between the two, I was able to eat plenty. One point off for not having the crispy vegetarian duck, which is a personal favourite. It's located right at the Westferry Canary Wharf TfL riverboat service, so after you've had your meal, you can walk out to a boat and be back at London Bridge or Embankment way faster than you could on the tube or DLR, plus a great view! We had one small child with the group, and they didn't seem phased by her running around a bit, and there were loads of families with kids, so I would say this is a kid-friendly spot at brunch, at least.

LutOlazq62MeKxyI-gzwLw.text: Ate here 10/2012 with 1 friend so I recall neither the dishes ordered nor their review other than:* immense construction outside was totally not heard indoors, kudos to that as locals know it was an immense amount of construction* very nice interior design, very comfortable* attentive high levels of service, commensurate with the price point* you get what you pay for so it was as good as hopedSorry I couldn't provide more detail, but wanted to record these for others.

HPd4lhOpWgQGKyEbj-UDjA.text: Royal China, Canary Wharf Riverside - we had a simple midweek dim sum lunch. If you are around Canary Wharf for lunch, notice the amount of people lunching outdoors when the sun is shinning. The square, park and along the river side are filled with people. You would think that would be no one dining in the restaurants. Oh yes, they were there too!I always felt that Royal China was somewhat classier. It was probably the colour scheme that gave that impression - gold against the black. Stepping into the restaurant, it was just an average Chinese restaurant. Perhaps with a slight touch of elegance, only a slight. I didn't know why I felt intimidated. Prices of the dim sum dishes were quite reasonable around £3.50 per dish and rice/noodle dishes at £10.00.The menu, like a book, had quite a good selection of dishes and not just an endless list of shifty combinations of meat and sauce. The recommended set menu also looks like a good combination of food if you want to feast on. Royal China is quite a classic Chinese restaurant in England with the usual favourites of aromatic crispy duck, lemon chicken, marinated shiitake mushrooms and Singapore noodles.crispy noodles with chicken £9.50 - the noodles had a good crunch, not undercooked, and the gravy sauce not too strachy or salty. Just the perfect balance with an assortment of crunchy vegetables. roast pork buns £3.50 - quite a meagre filling but I liked the bao. Soft, fluffy and steaming hot. Yummy!turnip cake with cured meat £3.50 - not a good texture. Looked good but failed to deliver in taste and the texture was mushy and felt wrong. fried yam paste meat dumplings £3.50 - my favourite dim sum! The pastry was a little too oily and filling,  too salty. Not pleasant. honey roast pork puff £3.50 - another must order dish for me at my dim sum outings. Nice!shanghai pork dumplings £3.50 - the pastry was quite thin and the soup in the dumpling was flavoursome. Pretty much average. plain chee cheung fun with peanut sauce £3.80 - I am always glad to try new variety of dim sums offered and I felt quite western when ordering this fusion dish. Well, I can say that I am definitely not ordering this dish again. The chee cheung fun alone also had a very funny texture - mushy, felt as though the proportion of flour was wrong or a substandard rice flour was used. Although I did enjoy the light afternoon dim sum lunch, I thought that the recommended  service charge of 13% was quite steep. A simple midweek dim sum lunch does not count. Definitely heading for my weekend dim sum lunch for a proper dim sum fix!

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. fried yam paste with yam dumplings 3.50
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. turnip cake with cured meat 3.50
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. plain chee cheung fun with peanut sauce 3.80

jjTDAzhAKY4inEoVT8TFSQ.text: I am not sure this branch lives up to its Royal China reputation that it's other branches does in Baker Street and Bayswater.  The dim sum was ok, but overpriced and service was slow and lacking.  Tea and hot water was brought to our table after the dim sum arrived and half way through our meal, and only after I chased it several times.  Not sure why it took so long, the restaurant was not even busy.  There is seating outside, with a view of the Thames, so would have been nice on a good day, but it had been raining when we arrived so we sat inside.  I probably will not hurry back or make the trek across London, only went there as I wanted to try Yi-Ban in Docklands but it was closed for a private function, and this was nearby.

aDOJcIV85ey9mjOBErL3Zw.text: Poor service - rude disengaged rushed. Waited 20 minutes after sitting down and finally had get up and ask for sever to come to table to take order. Food is mediocre and unremarkable. Decor tired. Would not recommend or return.

eA4JMw0mOjsogewoIooenw.text: While the food was impeccable but and it's a big but...they rushed us from the time we walked in the door. We were repeatedly told that we need to clear out in an hour and a half. The main server kept coming to us every 15 minutes and pointing at her watch reminding us just how log we had to finish our meal. We came here for a team lunch and were 10 of us, which meant finishing our meal in 1.5 hours basically meant ya rushing through our food!!!! Also, when we got around to ordering our desserts, our orders were taken and then a minute later we were blatantly told that since it takes time we couldn't have it. This was absolutely rubbish and it's sad because the food was actually good. But when our celebratory lunch turned into a rushed gobbling up of food even, it became imperative to give a negative review!!!!!!

CF0NUMWWTA225E76kqG3VA.text: This is the first Chines restaurant that i tried in London. Was very traditional. good food. Big portions. good price: 44.50 £ for 2 people, 3 dishes. Nice restaurant next to the river.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

s9fbY8PgJEp3qxotfQBNxw.text: It was a birthday treat and I had chosen Royal China Canary Wharf out of pure laziness and also due to the fact that the branch at Baker Street require reservations most of the time. While it was good, i can't help but feel that the standards are not up to scratch to the branch at Baker Street. My Chee Chong Fun had a pathetic amount of soy sauce and it was so dry it stuck together. What about the rest of my dim sum..? It was okayish. Oh and my food came lukewarm, not sure why. Sorry Royal China, I love the Baker Street branch but maybe not the one at Canary Wharf and it pains me to leave a bad review for this experience. However above all, the service here is decent. ;)

wQrgk7UYNwO_J8eDBmDvIw.text: This is the first Chinese food restaurant that I visited in London. It's along the Thames River in Canary Wharf, so it offers great views on the patio! The food selections are mostly Cantonese style dishes, including dim sum items. I went here for lunch and ordered mostly dim sum foods. The food is decent, I think the menu selection is a bit limited. Otherwise, I really enjoy the atmosphere there.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Crispy Abalone
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Seafood fried noodles

_rNhpGz9mDSH47N2SbCBIQ.text: Food is average.Service efficient but not very friendly.Prices okVery nice is the outdoor setting. You can sit in the shade under trees and watch the people along the river walk

xB6_uVTk8PR6GnS9Xtyyyg.text: Excellent pork buns and hot & sour soup.  The gyoza is plump and tasty. The location is great with views into the water. I recommend this place and will be back for sure.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Gyoza
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Minced pork & shrimp dumpling
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Pork buns- light and fluffy

yXFsnAVYdQgQLoRnKqXYeg.text: Other than the novelty of being able to eat yum cha Al fresco in the summer and the rare instance that lotus is closed (this being the case) i just don't get why anybody would eat here. The main plus is the decor which is nice and opulent and they have very plush restrooms. Unfortunately these are not my main criteria for choice of yum cha. Ordered similar dishes to always. The char siu sou had a very stingy char siu to sou ratio. Siu long bao - the skin was very good but the soup and filling were very bland. Gon chau ngou  hor (beef ho fun) was the best dish we had, I would have liked it to have more soy/seasoning but apparently that's just my gwai lo taste buds. The turnip paste was mushy, bland and just not nice. The veggie cheung fun was horrible - bad consistency of the Cheung fun and just a weird taste and aftertaste. The chicken feet were ok but let's be honest we're talking about chicken feet. The beef balls again were very bland.
